posts.name: 5089 Robonerds
posts.cooked: We recently purchased a new radio from WCP and we are having trouble trying to connect to it to update it and configure it with our team number. We are kind of lost and can’t find anything in the documentation and from the VividHosting website that works. We got the “ FRC -VIVIDHOSTING” network to show up as a WIFI network but we don’t have any security passkey for it. If anyone knows a way we can connect to it or if we’re doing something wrong help pls.

posts.name: Ege Saygılı
posts.cooked: I have read the documentation and I think although it is not explicitly stated you should be able to access the radio interface once you connect your computer to the radio using an ethernet cable using the DS port?

posts.name: Cameron (Advanced Programmer)
posts.cooked: 2024 Champs Radio at Home Control System

posts.name: 5089 Robonerds
posts.cooked: We tried to connect at the  192.168.69.1 address but whenever we connect it says  that we cannot get a connection or that it just doesn’t exist. We also tried disabling our wifi adapter with no success.

posts.name: 5089 Robonerds
posts.cooked: We are plugged in the entire time we are trying to connect as well.
I remember dealing with this problem as well, I think the radio is located somewhere like 10.0.1.1

posts.name: 5089 Robonerds
posts.cooked: It worked. Thank you.

posts.name: Bryn Dole - programming mentor FRC 2930
posts.cooked:
Is there some requirement that the driver station has to be connected to the port labeled “ DS ” ?

We also could not get DHCP to work and only when we manually configured TCP/IP to use the 10.0.1.0 subnet could we get a connection.

The configuration page on the radio doesn’t report the Firmware version. Good luck to any officials trying to enforce a particular firmware version for competition.

posts.name: Kiet Chau
posts.cooked:
randomstring:

We also could not get DHCP to work and only when we manually configured TCP/IP to use the 10.0.1.0 subnet could we get a connection.

The configuration page on the radio doesn’t report the Firmware version. Good luck to any officials trying to enforce a particular firmware version for competition.

Thanks for the feedback! We’re likely going to add the FW string and additional regulatory statements to the config page.

FYI, the enforcement of the firmware version will likely be at the radio kiosk.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: CEO @ Vivid-Hosting, Mentor @ Team 1538 / The Holy Cows

posts.custom_user_title: CEO @ Vivid-Hosting, Mentor @ Team 1538 / The Holy Cows

posts.name: Larry Bolan
posts.cooked: Silly question: will the Kiosk have any ability to perform the update as well? Or just a “Sorry about your luck, please update and try again later”?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Manufacturing Engineer by day, FRC Scorekeeper by night

posts.custom_user_title: Manufacturing Engineer by day, FRC Scorekeeper by night

posts.name: Kiet Chau
posts.cooked:
ratdude747:

Or just a “Sorry about your luck, please update and try again later”?

LOL! No, planning to have it push updates. In addition, the kiosk will have the ability to push “hot patches”, effectively reducing the firmware update time to a few seconds if the version installed has an applicable upgrade path, otherwise a full update would be pushed (minutes)

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: CEO @ Vivid-Hosting, Mentor @ Team 1538 / The Holy Cows

posts.custom_user_title: CEO @ Vivid-Hosting, Mentor @ Team 1538 / The Holy Cows

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked:
randomstring:

The configuration page on the radio doesn’t report the Firmware version. Good luck to any officials trying to enforce a particular firmware version for competition.

There is no inspection requirement in the current rules for a particular firmware for the radio. Presumably the program your radio for the event takes care of this.
the current/old radio programmer handles this as well it will force a firmware update before programming if needed, so in a roundabout way it is required

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: That is true but the robot rules say have your radio programed at the event. It doesn’t specify a specific firmware other than you have to use the event’s tool to do so. So as an RI , I don’t care. The ultimate consequence is unless the radio is properly programmed, it will not connect to the field. You will be sad. Your alliance partners, Maybe yes. Maybe no.

posts.name: Bryn Dole - programming mentor FRC 2930
posts.cooked:
@kiettyyyy is there a requirement that the driver station is plugged into the “ DS ” port? Other than POE in/out on the ports is there any difference in how DHCP, switching, routing is handled for the ports?

The example diagrams show using the DS port for adding an additional switch and connecting the driver station, is this just a convention (say to avoid the POE ports) or is it a requirement to wire them this way?

The documentation needs fewer FCC warnings and caveats, hide the internal wiring schematics to some deep page, move the “Programming your Radio” section from the hidden under the “Usage” tab (that is the 9th item on the list) to hit’s own top level line item closer to the top, make a “quickstart” guide, change the instructions so that 50% of the text isn’t in blue or red boxes (if everything is an exception, nothing is the instructions). The radiation pattern is super cool, but arguably non-actionable to the majority of FIRST students, that should be secondary not come above how to configure the radio, or even what the LEDs mean.

I’ve read the whole web page and I’m still left wondering if I can connect to the robot directly without use of a second radio as the AP. At competition? at home?  What is the behavior if I don’t set DIP switch 3 (I only found documentation for when it is set ON not OFF).

Is the radio suppose to work with DHCP out of the box? Because the radio setup instructions say it does. They also say that you can access the radio on 92.168.69.2 but neither was the case for me.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked:
randomstring:

I’ve read the whole web page and I’m still left wondering if I can connect to the robot directly without use of a second radio as the AP. At competition? at home? What is the behavior if I don’t set DIP switch 3 (I only found documentation for when it is set ON not OFF).

I am not Kiet but I will try to answer some of your questions.

When 2.4K is on (SW3) the radio functions as an AP on 2.4.  If finds a 6E AP that it is configured for it will connect and switch to 6E as a bridge and disable the  2.4G .

I thought the 6E AP was disabled. The directions seem to say different. It gives directions to configure it as a 6E AP with the stipulation that it cannot be battery powered in that mode. So you cannot legally use that mode on a battery powered robot regardless.

At competition it acts much the same as the old radio. Except it works better. You cannot connect wireless to the robot except through FMS (also simplified)

You don’t set dp3 ON then it is a 6E bridge. flipping the switch resets the radio config. At least the champs version did.

The failsafe IP of the radio is  192.168.69.2 you have to be on the correct subnet to access at that IP

I except we are going to use the old radios at home because we prefer the less cluttered 5G band. (compared to the 2.4G

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
FrankJ:

I except we are going to use the old radios at home because we prefer the less cluttered 5G band. (compared to the 2.4G

Note if you buy two radios, you can have one wall-powered to be the 6GHz AP, and the robot as a 6GHz bridge just like at an event.  Then you can connect to the AP from your laptop(s) with Ethernet to talk to the robot.  This will give an even better experience than 5GHz direct from laptops, given that laptop WiFi cards aren’t great, and 6GHz is even less cluttered than 5.  The only downside is needing another radio to be the AP.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: If you do that, be sure to heats sink the field side one.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
When configured as a WIRELESS ACCESS POINT , due to regulatory requirements, the VH-109 radio cannot be powered using a battery source and is for Indoor Use Only .

Is this only a legal restriction, or is the radio also doing something to detect that it is powered from a battery?  If the former, it would be better to say “may not”.  If the latter, are there circumstances under which it would trigger incorrectly?

randomstring:

Other than POE in/out on the ports is there any difference in how DHCP, switching, routing is handled for the ports?

https://frc-radio.vivid-hosting.net/overview/ports

According to the documentation, in addition to being incapable of PoE, the DS port is the only port capable of GigE.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
bovlb:

Is this only a legal restriction, or is the radio also doing something to detect that it is powered from a battery? If the former, it would be better to say “may not”. If the latter, are there circumstances under which it would trigger incorrectly?

My understanding is it’s both.  And Vivid can’t state publicly the trigger conditions because of the legal requirements (e.g. if they say what they are, it’s basically giving people the instructions to intentionally bypass that restriction).  As it sounds like this is the very first FCC approved device to have this feature (both 6GHz AP and 6 GHz bridge modes available selectively based on mobile/fixed usage), they’re being understandably very careful about this.
